Profile

An electrical engineer with solid background in scientific computing to create predictive models using high performance cloud computing tools.

Experience

Engineering Intern 3

June 2018 – August 2018, Coventor, Inc., A Lam Research Company.

Worked in software development team to develop and validate new modeling approaches to address process, device, and/or circuit level challenges for semiconductor devices. I have validated the netlisting capabilities of SEMulator3D tool by studying the parasitic effects through static timing analysis using HSPICE. Also, implemented a model using python API to simulate quantum tunneling in metal-oxide-metal junctions.

Graduate Research Assistant

September 2014 – Present, NET Lab, University of Massachusetts – Amherst

Modeling of low-dimensional materials to study their electrical and thermal properties. I have implemented predictive models using high performance cloud computing tools to study probabilistic and quantum systems

Graduate Teaching Assistant

January 2015 – Present, University of Massachusetts – Amherst

ECE-344 Semiconductor Devices and Materials (Fall 2015, Fall 2017, Fall 2018), ECE-231 Introduction to Embedded systems (Spring 2019), ECE-232 Hardware Organization and Design (Spring 2017), ECE-354 Computer Systems Lab-II (Spring 2015).

Research Projects

High throughput 2D material discovery for thermoelectric applications: predicting power factor using physics aware models.*

Phonon drag contribution towards TE performance in MoS2: Using full phonon distribution.*

Towards a higher power factor in 2D materials: Role of inelastic scattering mechanisms.*

Thermoelectric properties of periodic quantum structures in the Wigner-Rode formalism.

We developed a comprehensive transport model using the Wigner–Rode formalism to study in tunneling in semiconducting nanostructures. We include the full electronic bandstructure and all the relevant scattering mechanisms, allowing us to simulate both energy relaxation and quantum effects from periodic potential barriers. We study the impact of barrier shape on TE performance and find that tall, sharp barriers with small period lengths lead to the largest increase in both Seebeck coefficient and conductivity, thus boosting power factor and TE efficiency.
Journal paper

Low-temperature enhancement of the thermoelectric Seebeck coefficient in gated semiconductor nanomembranes.

Fowler-Nordheim emission in surface modified free-standing diamond nanomembranes.

*Ongoing project
